vulnerability_findings.name: inefficient-state-variable-increment
vulnerability_findings.message: <x> += <y> costs more gas than <x> = <x> + <y> for state variables.

vulnerability_findings.name: init-variables-with-default-value
vulnerability_findings.message: Uninitialized variables are assigned with the types default value. Explicitly initializing a variable with its default value costs unnecessary gas.

vulnerability_findings.name: use-multiple-require
vulnerability_findings.message: Using multiple require statements is cheaper than using && multiple check combinations. There are more advantages, such as easier to read code and better coverage reports.

vulnerability_findings.name: erc20-interface
vulnerability_findings.message:
CDEXTokenContract (CDEX_rewards.sol#224-230) has incorrect ERC20 function interface(s):
	-transfer (CDEX_rewards.sol#227)

vulnerability_findings.name: reentrancy-no-eth
vulnerability_findings.message:
Reentrancy in CDEXStakingPool.exit (CDEX_rewards.sol#452-455):
	External calls:
	- withdraw(_balances[msg.sender]) (CDEX_rewards.sol#453)
	- getReward() (CDEX_rewards.sol#454)
	State variables written after the call(s):
	- _status (CDEX_rewards.sol#454)
	- committedRewardTokens (CDEX_rewards.sol#454)
	- depositedRewardTokens (CDEX_rewards.sol#454)
	- lastUpdateTime (CDEX_rewards.sol#454)
	- loyaltyBonuses (CDEX_rewards.sol#454)
	- rewardPerTokenStored (CDEX_rewards.sol#454)
	- rewards (CDEX_rewards.sol#454)
	- userRewardPerTokenPaid (CDEX_rewards.sol#454)

vulnerability_findings.name: reentrancy-no-eth
vulnerability_findings.message:
Reentrancy in CDEXStakingPool.stake (CDEX_rewards.sol#365-394):
	External calls:
	- CDEXRanking.insert(amount,msg.sender) (CDEX_rewards.sol#379)
	- CDEXRanking.remove(_balances[msg.sender],msg.sender) (CDEX_rewards.sol#382)
	- CDEXRanking.insert(_balances[msg.sender].add(amount),msg.sender) (CDEX_rewards.sol#384)
	State variables written after the call(s):
	- _balances (CDEX_rewards.sol#387)

vulnerability_findings.name: reentrancy-no-eth
vulnerability_findings.message:
Reentrancy in CDEXStakingPool.withdraw (CDEX_rewards.sol#398-421):
	External calls:
	- CDEXRanking.remove(_balances[msg.sender],msg.sender) (CDEX_rewards.sol#407)
	State variables written after the call(s):
	- _balances (CDEX_rewards.sol#409)

vulnerability_findings.name: reentrancy-benign
vulnerability_findings.message:
Reentrancy in CDEXStakingPool.withdraw (CDEX_rewards.sol#398-421):
	External calls:
	- CDEXRanking.remove(_balances[msg.sender],msg.sender) (CDEX_rewards.sol#407)
	State variables written after the call(s):
	- totalMembers (CDEX_rewards.sol#412)

vulnerability_findings.name: timestamp
vulnerability_findings.vulnerability_code:
function min(uint256 a, uint256 b) public pure returns (uint256) {

        return a < b ? a : b;
vulnerability_findings.message:
CDEXStakingPool.min (CDEX_rewards.sol#343-345) uses timestamp for comparisons
	Dangerous comparisons:
	- a < b (CDEX_rewards.sol#344)

vulnerability_findings.name: timestamp
vulnerability_findings.message:
CDEXStakingPool.notifyRewardAmount (CDEX_rewards.sol#503-532) uses timestamp for comparisons
	Dangerous comparisons:
	- block.timestamp >= periodFinish (CDEX_rewards.sol#514-520)
	- require(bool)(rewardRate <= depositedRewardTokens.div(rewardsDuration)) (CDEX_rewards.sol#525)

vulnerability_findings.name: timestamp
vulnerability_findings.message:
CDEXStakingPool.setRewardsDuration (CDEX_rewards.sol#537-544) uses timestamp for comparisons
	Dangerous comparisons:
	- require(bool)(block.timestamp > periodFinish) (CDEX_rewards.sol#539)

vulnerability_findings.name: external-function
vulnerability_findings.message: CDEXStakingPool.depositTokens (CDEX_rewards.sol#483-497) should be declared external

vulnerability_findings.name: external-function
vulnerability_findings.message: CDEXStakingPool.notifyRewardAmount (CDEX_rewards.sol#503-532) should be declared external

vulnerability_findings.name: Dependence on predictable environment variable (SWC 116)
vulnerability_findings.message:
A control flow decision is made based on The block.timestamp environment variable.
The block.timestamp environment variable is used to determine a control flow decision. Note that the values of variables like coinbase, gaslimit, block number and timestamp are predictable and can be manipulated by a malicious miner. Also keep in mind that attackers know hashes of earlier blocks. Don't use any of those environment variables as sources of randomness and be aware that use of these variables introduces a certain level of trust into miners.
Classification: SWC-116

vulnerability_findings.name: Dependence on predictable environment variable (SWC 116)

Classification: SWC-116

vulnerability_findings.name: External Call To User-Supplied Address (SWC 107)
vulnerability_findings.message:
A call to a user-supplied address is executed.
An external message call to an address specified by the caller is executed. Note that the callee account might contain arbitrary code and could re-enter any function within this contract. Reentering the contract in an intermediate state may lead to unexpected behaviour. Make sure that no state modifications are executed after this call and/or reentrancy guards are in place.
Classification: SWC-107

vulnerability_findings.name: State access after external call (SWC 107)
vulnerability_findings.message:
Read of persistent state following external call
The contract account state is accessed after an external call to a user defined address. To prevent reentrancy issues, consider accessing the state only before the call, especially if the callee is untrusted. Alternatively, a reentrancy lock can be used to prevent untrusted callees from re-entering the contract in an intermediate state.
Classification: SWC-107

vulnerability_findings.name: State access after external call (SWC 107)

vulnerability_findings.name: Multiple Calls in a Single Transaction (SWC 113)
vulnerability_findings.message:
Multiple calls are executed in the same transaction.
This call is executed following another call within the same transaction. It is possible that the call never gets executed if a prior call fails permanently. This might be caused intentionally by a malicious callee. If possible, refactor the code such that each transaction only executes one external call or make sure that all callees can be trusted (i.e. they’re part of your own codebase).
Classification: SWC-113
